title: Unleashing the Potential Blocked in Negativity

author: Marjeta Novak, Humus, d. o. o.

segmentation: First of all, my deep respect to everyone here.
Sitting already for like 4 hours or so without a break and still following all these inspiring talks while I'm quite enjoying to see this.
OK, what am I my credentials for?
Speaking about negativity?
First of all I was born in Slovenia back then Yugoslavia, and since my first day of life, I was bummed with.
Be pregnant and Creedon, which is something that all civilians here now an finance Venus.
It is close to obedience, but it basically means do not disturb.
Do not disturb the system.
The parents, other adults just fit in, which is not very conducive to creativity really.
The next thing was my school system, which is not really based on.
Knowledge, but on the lack of knowledge, so the more imperfections the teachers discover, the lesser great you get.
And Thirdly I was trained as a journalist and of course a good journalist is the person who finds fault with the system person who criticizes who's even cynical.
And of course, the result of this is twofold.
One is yes.
Journalists are doing their role and finding places where SoC government should improve.
Should you find better solutions, but Secondly also when you open the newspaper in the morning or a TV channel in the evening, your spirits somehow go down.
Especially now is living in this recession because all we get this all this bad news and.
Pessimistic views there is no future real just going down down down, down to this downward spiral.
And so by the time I was an adult, I was pretty good at giving negative feedback myself as well.
And now Fast forward 20 years I work in two fields.
One is as an intercultural list.
I'm trying to help people collaborate better across.
Nations across generational divides across organizational cultures.
Secondly, I work as a group process facilitator helping groups reach their goals by acting as sort of a referee in the football field and providing structure providing process and.
Taking care of the communication that's happening so that people really hear each other and collaborate on each others ideas.
And what I have really learned in these two fields is perhaps two things.

One is that yes, really in Slovenia if I compare it to some other work environments where where I work as well, we do have a bit more pessimistic outlook on life on future As for example Anglo Saxon environments do.
And Secondly, even though there is a lot of.
Fear of change, fear of what the future would bring people.
Nevertheless, in the groups I work with the work better if we work on their strengths rather than weaknesses.
If we explore what works well in a system or another organization or in a team rather than if we explore what doesn't work because there's this gets us very often stuck and feeling.
I'm happy and doesn't give us that much energy.
But there is also good news about it because.
Where there is a lot of negativity, there is also a lot of passion.
Because if you didn't care about something, you would not even complain.
You just say well, why bother?
It doesn't doesn't mean anything to me.
So this means that even here within Slovenia we have huge amounts of energy and passion and demonstration of how things are meaningful to us.
But of course there very often expressed in a way that's not the most constructive so.

Let's let's think of a contest where we have a team that is trying to devise some new creative solutions, maybe for a product for service for their new relationship structures, and if it's a very good team or if it has a very good facilitator, then perhaps the idea generation phase when people come up with ideas, this goes pretty smoothly because people know that you know in a brainstorming you should not criticize and sometimes this even happens.
But of course, when we start looking at ideas, let's say that we do have one idea that has potential.
I'm sure many of you have already experienced that we get.
We hear a lot, like, yeah, you know, we've tried it.
It doesn't work.
You are such a realistic person, etc.
Or we haven't got resources.
This doesn't seem to work too well.
It's possible to rearrange it so that people can read.
I didn't mean this, but just the.
Slide.
No, no, it's OK alright thank you yeah.
And of course we are very familiar with this, and this is for me.
It's a breakthrough opportunity because.
Yes, of course we can go along in the same line, and you know either direct attention to something else or or comfort people or even criticize the criticizer like you shouldn't criticize.

You shouldn't be critical by which we are doing the same thing and what I see here, it's really the fight or flight response that we were talking to already today when people feel threatened, you know, I'm threatened by this new idea.
And this fight and flight response might be OK if you're walking through Union Woods and your step on a bear in a forest, then this is the proper thing to do.
But maybe in these collaborative settings that could be better way.
So better opportunities out there we were talking about opportunities today.
So.
Again, I ask myself, as a facilitator, is there a way to somehow tap all that passion that is invested into our criticizing?
Just think of all the time we spent blaming moaning, complaining, inning or in a work setting in our homes as well.
Even without friends you have a debate over a Cup of coffee and in 5 minutes it's almost destined to go into you know all these.
They are the politicians.
The bosses are well, my husband etc.
But again it means that there is.
Something we care about and.
The longer I work with people the brochure am that there is always a message.
We are told to bring out, but we don't know how.
So we act like children.
You know I'm not happy about this and how you should do that.
I'm worried about this and but in fact.
There's always some underlying quality need or value that is dear to us.
This is just linking to the presentation that was here before.
How important it is to unearth the values.
The positive drivers that drive our work, our thinking, our community.
Dating with others, and that's what I tried to implement in my work as well.
And it works wonders.
It really creates magical moment in Group.
Let's just give a few examples like OK, you hear this one.
We've tried it all before.
This won't work, so so they're just trying to ask people.
OK, So what is meaningful to you is that we really do use your out time sensibly.
Because it means a lot to you that we really put the meaningful things in meaningful amounts of times.
And people say yes.
Or perhaps they said no, that's not what I'm worried about.
You know, I'm just worried that we we are.
I would want to be more successful in our tries.
Perhaps give it more thought or whatever.
People will respond.
And some more examples.
You always come up with such unrealistic ideas here, so you would like.

For us to be more practical, yes, of course, and perhaps more efficient and have is common reality of what's happening or OK, so you're worried that your employees would be spending long hours here and you're worried about their health and well being and their families itself.
And of course it's not so linear.
But OK, so I will add the missing piece there.
What I have seen is then when people are invited to connect with what they really value, what's meaningful to them?
What they really care about.
They just shine.
So this downward spiral is somehow turned up.
And even more when they are connected to their very best or even to what they could be.
If there are very best, then other people can connect to that light in them.
They see them as beautiful people really, maybe even just for a second.
But it's enough for a transformation.
You just see everything differently.
Again, if applied to the model before it means connecting for a second.
Not just mentale person spiritually, even aesthetically to the other person.
Even more so, research has shown this generative connection.
This is taken from Ronald Fryan others who are working with appreciative inquiry.
They have discovered that.

When connection happens between people, they wants to not just understand a bit more the other person, but even want to do something about it so that these concerns that this person has expressed, say for the work balance or for efficiency or for a good use of resources, that this be somehow included in our plans.
So how to find a solution that will accommodate my own values and your own?
As well, or perhaps find another sphere, another time where I will give voice to this concern that we will take them seriously.
Because otherwise if we don't take these concerns seriously, we will erode the trust that we are talking.
We were eroded, people's commitment to whatever decisions we will make because the concerns will come up later.
Maybe once we've already made a expensive business plans and put a lot of resources into it.
And people say, oh.
Anyway, I never really supported that idea, so it's important to give room and voice to these concern and hopefully in a way that really brings the best out of people.
And let me finish with the story.
It's a Cherokee story about a Gran father who was talking to his grandson about a battle that's going on in all of us.
And he says, you know, my son in our heads there are two Wolves fighting all the time.
The first one is.
The evil Wolf.
It's about anger, envy, jealousy, sorrow, regard.
Greet arrogance.
You can all read superiority and ego in the end.
And there's the other Wolf, the Wolf.
Of good which is joy, peace, love, hope, serenity, humility, kindness, benevolence, empathy, generosity, truth.
Compassion and faith.
And the little boy was thoughtful for a minute and I asked.
So which Wolf wins?
The old Cherokee guys gave a very simple answer.
The one you feed.
And with this I'd like to finish my presentation and perhaps just one last thought that in my experience, empathy for the other person.
Is one of the least utilized and least esteemed resources that we have in our organizations.
And of course, if you want to be a thriving organization, you should empathize.
Of course with your clients with your customers.
With your patience, whoever you are providing service or product Stew.
And of course you should empathize with your employees as well.
Beat your bosses or sub organ ordinates.

And because this is when real transformation can happen between people and it also can pave the way for any collaboration that will really be meaningful, not just for ourselves but also for others and for the whole planet.
So thank you.
Thank you Maria.
One question for you.
Do you think that transformation is needed to be more innovative person in as individuals?
I don't know if it's needed, if it works without its transformation for anyone, that's great, but of course it's a faster way to come to a next phase.
The questions, however, what to do to come to a transformation?
And for me, one of really one of the tools is just to connect on a human to human basis for a short while, and from here on we can then create worlds together.
But this is just one of the tools.
I'm sure there are many others.
Out there.
Thank you, thank you.
